H0.text: Decreasing the pitch changes the loudness of sound.

H1.text: Increasing the frequency can change the loudness of sound.

H2.text: Increasing the amplitude is a way to change the loudness of sound.

H3.text: Decreasing the wavelength can change the loudness of sound.

A4.text: The perception of loudness is related to sound pressure level (SPL).

A5.text: The sensitivity of the human ear changes as a function of frequency, as shown in the equal-loudness graph.

A6.text: The sound pressure level (SPL) or Lp is defined as 10 log10(p^2 / prefp^2) = 20 log10(p / prefp) dB, where p is the root-mean-square sound pressure.

A7.text: A-weighting attempts to match the response of the human ear to noise and A-weighted sound pressure levels are labeled dBA.

A8.text: Stanford scientists created a sound so loud it instantly boils water
